DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC

FOMC lifted the Fed Funds Rate to 1.75%-2.00% as expected and sees 4 hikes in 2018 (Prev. estimated 3 hikes). (Newswires)
Fed repeated that monetary policy stance remains accommodative.
Fed stated that economic activity is rising at a solid rate vs. previous statement that growth was moderate.
Fed also hiked the IOER by 25bps to 1.95% or 5bps below the top range of FFR as it aims to keep market rates well within range.
Fed dropped reference from previous statements that it expected rates to be below neutral for ‘some time’.

FOMC Projections
Fed now sees a total of 4 hikes this year vs. Prev. estimate of 3 hikes but maintained its forecasts for rates in the long run at 2.9%.
Fed raised GDP forecast for this year to 2.8% from 2.7% but maintained GDP forecasts for the years after.
Fed lowered its Unemployment Rate forecasts through to 2020 and raised PCE inflation estimate for this year and next to 2.1%.

Fed Chair Powell said the Fed is to hold a press conference after every meeting beginning in January but added this does not signal a change in policy and is about improving communications.
Fed’s Powell said Federal agents are showing concerns on US trade policy but they do not currently see any impact of trade policy on data.
Fed’s Powell stated FOMC has been careful not to tighten policy too quickly and that it has been patient.
Fed’s Powell also noted there was wide uncertainty around NAIRU and the neutral rate, while he added the Fed will keep an open mind and is monitoring incoming data.

ASIA-PAC

US is reportedly preparing to proceed on imposing tariffs on Chinese goods with the decision awaiting US President Trump’s final approval, while reports also noted the US is preparing a focused list of goods which will be subject to tariffs as soon as Friday. (WSJ) In related news, US President Trump will meet with top trade advisers on Thursday regarding decision whether to proceed with China tariffs. (Newswires)
 

UK

House of Commons voted to reject House of Lords amendments to the EU Withdrawal Bill which would have required the Government to seek to negotiate a customs union as part of the framework for a future UK-EU relationship and which would have made the UK's full access to the EU internal market a negotiating objective of the Government. (Newswires)

UK PM May’s truce with proâ€‘EU rebels close to collapse, according to reports. (The Times)

UK CPI YY (May) 2.4% vs. Exp. 2.5% (Prev. 2.4%). (Newswires)


EU

German Economy Minister Altmaier said they were unsuccessful in EU in stopping spiral of tariffs, while he also stated that US competitors will be hurt by US tariffs and that Europe will have a joint response to the tariffs. Altmaier added the EU must make sure there is no abundance of steel in the German and European markets following the tariff decision from the US, while he also noted that the EU currently discussing quotas on steel imports to prevent flooding of market. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks (8 Jun) -4.143M vs. Exp. -1.440M (Prev. 2.072M); production +0.93% at 10.90mln. (Newswires)

Russian oil production was at 11.1mln BPD from June 1-12th, higher than OPEC+ oil cut deal, according to sources. In other news, Russia is to propose to participants of the oil output cut deal that they increase output in line with quotas, in order to remove the risk of the market overheating, according to a government source. (Newswires)

Iran OPEC governor sees OPEC officials sticking with the supply pact this year and says oil markets do not need any extra supply. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he would like to achieve major Korean disarmament within two and a half years. (Newswires)


US

US PPI Final Demand MM (May) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires)
US PPI Final Demand YY (May) 3.1% vs. Exp. 2.8% (Prev. 2.6%)
 

MARKET RECAP

The S&P 500 Emini was trading sideways overnight and through the European day as we approached the FOMC rate announcement, clinging to levels just above 2790; The initial hawkish interpretation of the Fed’s decision, statement, and forecasts so knee-jerk selling across the equity complex, though as Fed chair Powell delivered his press conference, losses were pared back, with the ES finding its way back to the 2790+ area. SPX -0.40%, NDX -0.05 %, DJI -0.47%.

Treasuries were very much rangebound for most of the session heading into the FOMC rate decision, with thin volume seen across the complex. Post-Fed, however, there was knee-jerk selling with the rate decision and guidance perceived as hawkish, and Treasuries sold-off falling from 119-13+ to 119-03; the 10yr yield rose back above 3% hitting a three-week high, and the 2yr yields extended gains above peaks seen in August 2008 given its sensitivity the Fed.  The yield curve bear flattened (Fed Chair Powell said the yield curve is flattening because Fed is lifting the federal funds rate), with 2yr and 5yr higher by c.4bps and 30y higher by c.1bps. 5s30s spread narrowed to beneath 25bps for the first time since 2007. US 10YR T-notes futures (Sep 2018) settle 7 ticks lower at 119-06.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 13th June 2018 - Markets unphased by FOMC hike
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • * SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries down, DXY down, Crude up.
  • * REAR-VIEW: FOMC hikes, adds fourth 2018 dot; US PPI small beat; IEA warns on supply shocks.
  • * AHEAD: Australia labour market; ECB Rate Decision; UK and US Retail Sales; US Jobless Claims; German and Swedish CPI.

 

* FED: The FOMC lifted the fed funds rate target corridor to 1.75%-2.00%, as expected; over the course of its forecast horizon, it added a hike, and now foresees a total of four rate rises in 2018 (previously saw three hikes), three in 2019 (unchanged) and two in 2020 (unchanged). The Committee repeated its stance that monetary policy remains accommodative, and also upgraded its language on the economy; economic activity is rising at a ‘solid’ rate, previously said growth was ‘moderate’. It dropped its reference from previous statements that it expected rates to be below neutral for ‘some time’. Elsewhere, it hiked the IOER by 20bps to 1.95%. In his post-meeting press conference, Fed chair Powell was upbeat about the US economy, suggesting it was in ‘good shape’. said he’d be concerned if inflation was persistently above or below 2%, though his views haven’t changed much since the March meeting. Powell believes that inflation will be pushed above the 2% target after the oil price rise recently, but sees it as transitory. On the inflation target itself, Powell said the FOMC is strongly committed to the 2% price goal, and the barriers to changing that are very high. On trade policy, Powell noted Fed contacts had reported concerns on trade policy, though he is not seeing any evidence of it in the economic data. Powell said there was wide uncertainty around NAIRU and the neutral rate, and the Fed will keep an open mind, and is monitor incoming data.

* TRADE: US President Donald Trump could slap fresh tariffs on China, perhaps as soon as Friday, a move analysts say may sour negotiations between the two nations, as it appeared the situation was improving. The US was said to be preparing a honed list of goods subject to tariffs to be announced on Friday, as the exact amount of Chinese goods subject to tariffs is being finalised. China earlier said it was to further increase imports; previously the nation had said it was willing to boost imports If US meets halfway on trade. Elsewhere, German Economy Minister Altmaier said they have not been successful in EU in stopping spiral of tariffs. He added US competitors will be hurt by US tariffs, noting Europe will have a joint response to the tariffs. He warned EU must make sure there is no abundance of steel in the German and European markets following the tariff decision from the US. Finally he announced the EU is currently discussing quotas on steel imports to prevent flooding of market.

* GEOPOLITICS: US Secretary of State Pompeo said he would like to achieve major Korean disarmament within two and a half years.

* BREXIT: A minister reported that EU chief Brexit negotiator Barnier and European Commission President Juncker are to visit Ireland next week. Ireland's Europe minister Macentee said Ireland welcomes elements of a UK Brexit plan, adding the country is not looking to pause Brexit talks and wants more discussions, and said Ireland is seeking Brexit deal by October. The House of Commons voted 322 to 240 to reject amendment (a) to Lords amendment 51 to the EU Withdrawal Bill which would have made the UK's full access to the EU internal market a negotiating objective of the Government. The House of Commons voted 327 to 126 to reject amendment (b) 51 which would have called on the Government to make continued participation in the European Economic Area (EEA) a negotiating objective. Finally, the House of Commons voted 325 to 298 to reject Lords amendment 1 to the EU Withdrawal Bill which would have required the Government to seek to negotiate a customs union as part of the framework for a future UK-EU relationship.

* DATA: US PPI ticked up in May to 2.4% from 2.3%, beating expectations. The monthly figure also beat the consensus of 0.3% coming in at 0.5%. The latest producer prices and yesterday’s CPI release both confirm that price pressure is building up in the economy, Capital Economics said. The rebound in PPIs was mostly attributed to higher energy prices and partially by raw material inflation which has pushed higher on the back of tariffs. PPI Ex-Food/Energy/Trade remained unchanged at 0.1%. The latest inflation figures back the Fed view of hiking rates once a quarter, CapEco said.

* SPX -0.40%, NDX -0.05 %, DJI -0.47%. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.27%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.04%, Energy: -0.07%, Financials: -0.42%, Health Care: -0.08%, Industrials: -0.61%, Materials: -0.96%, Telecoms: -4.40%, Tech: +0.18%, Utilities: +0.06%. The S&P 500 Emini was trading sideways overnight and through the European day as we approached the FOMC rate announcement, clinging to levels just above 2790; The initial hawkish interpretation of the Fed’s decision, statement, and forecasts so knee-jerk selling across the equity complex, though as Fed chair Powell delivered his press conference, losses were pared back, with the ES finding its way back to the 2790+ area.

* M&A: Aftermarket Tuesday, AT&T (T) won approval to purchase Time Warner (TWX) for USD 85bln and as a result many M&A names saw hefty moves, IE Fox (FOXA) saw intraday highs of around 7.5%, but potential bidders Comcast (CMCSA) and Disney (DIS) were hit pre-market (more so CMCSA), but the two both gradually pared back the losses, and Disney (DIS) extended gains to almost 4%; however, some were questioning whether DIS will actually be able to acquire Fox assets. Other names in the M&A space also caught a bid following the decision, such as Aetna (AET), CVS (CVS) and Express Scripts (ESRX).  Elsewhere, Stryker (SYK) reported in a filing that it is not in deal talks with Boston Scientifics (BSX), reversing some of the moves we saw when the deal was announced.

* EARNINGS: HR Block (HRB) reported strong numbers, however its revenue forecasts for FY19 were below expectations, and its EBITDA profit margin for the same period were lower than its FY18 figure; the co. also announced it is to shut 400 of its smaller offices, which saw the stock lower by almost 20% on Wednesday.  Elsewhere in stock specifics Netflix (NFLX) outperformed the SPX following a price target increase from Goldman Sachs to $490, which is a new street high.

* WTI FUTURES (N8) SETTLE UP 28 CENTS AT $66.64/BBL; BRENT (Q8) SETTLES UP 86 CENTS  AT $76.74/BBL. The DOE weekly inventory data showed a larger than expected draw for headline crude stocks – contrary to what was hinted in the API data on Tuesday – with inventories falling by 4.143mln (exp. -1.440mln, API reported +800k); Cushing Stocks drew 687k barrels (vs API -730k); gasoline Stocks drew down by a deeper than expected 2.271mln (exp. 0.433mln, API +2.33mln), and distillate inventories fell 2.101mln (exp. +200k, API +2.1mln); US crude production rose by 0.9% in the week to 10.9mln BPD. The IEA monthly report saw global demand estimates unchanged at 1.4mln BPD, though it raised its estimated for non-OPEC supply growth to 2mln BPD, and sounded the alarm on Venezuela and Iran, which the IEA says could shave 1.5mln BPD of crude off the market by the end of the year; it also warned that the supply disruptions could place pressure on the thin levels of spare capacity. The report comes ahead of next week’s OPEC+ meeting, where it is expected to ease supply curbs to offset outages from Venezuela and Angola, and anticipated supply disruptions from Iran. The Iranians today called on OPEC+ to maintain the current status quo; the plea came after reports suggested that the Russians were to propose OPEC+ share out the 1.8mln quota between members, leaving the 1mln BPD of voluntary cuts intact (today, government sources in Russia said President Putin does not plan to discuss exit from global oil output deal with Saudi Crown Prince). It was also reported that Russian crude production had climbed to 11.1mln BPD – in line with sources reports from the first part of the week. Reports on Wednesday stated that the Saudis are to consider a number of options at next week’s meeting, with one option being touted a 500k-700k BPD one-off hike. Meanwhile, ahead of next week’s meeting – and amid US consumers facing high pump prices heading into the midterms in November – US President Donald Trump once again ratcheted-up criticism of OPEC, tweeting that “oil prices are too high, OPEC is at it again. Not good!”

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (SEP 2018) SETTLE 7 TICKS LOWER AT 119-06. Treasuries were very much rangebound for most of the session heading into the FOMC rate decision, with thin volume seen across the complex. Post-Fed, however, there was knee-jerk selling with the rate decision and guidance perceived as hawkish, and Treasuries sold-off falling from 119-13+ to 119-03; the 10yr yield rose back above 3% hitting a three-week high, and the 2yr yields extended gains above peaks seen in August 2008 given its sensitivity the Fed.  The yield curve bear flattened (Fed Chair Powell said the yield curve is flattening because Fed is lifting the federal funds rate), with 2yr and 5yr higher by c.4bps and 30y higher by c.1bps. 5s30s spread narrowed to beneath 25bps for the first time since 2007.

* FOREX: The Dollar Index was in negative territory heading into the FOMC’s rate decision, and was boosted after the central bank hiked rates, lifted its trajectory of rate rises, and sounded upbeat on the economy. But with that said, the price action wasn’t spectacular, and major FX pairs remain confined to recent range, and as Powell was giving his press conference, news that the US was preparing to place tariffs on China resulted in the dollar paring gains. EURUSD traded between 1.1725-1.1792 ahead of the ECB decision tomorrow; USDJPY action was comatose, but has managed to stay above the 200dma. USDCAD continues to straddle the 1.30 figure; GBP around the 1.3350 level as the rest of the EU Withdrawal Bill amendments comes in as expected, EURGBP made an attempt to move to the top of its recent range around 0.8840 but couldn’t quite reach those levels, though remains above 0.88. The Antipodeans saw some downside after the FOMC decision, but the AUD remains above 0.7550, and NZD remains above 0.70. In the EMFX complex, BRL was up against the buck as the BCB continues its aggressive intervention; ZAR weakness was modest as we approach 13.50, as was the MXN, which is flattish around 20.68; TRY, however, has large external dollar cost funding, and accordingly weakened by over 1% vs the buck. 

* COMING-UP: ECB Monetary Policy Decision due at 12:45 BST/ EDT on Thursday 14th June 2018, press conference due at 13:30 BST/08:30 EDT. Unanimous expectations look for the ECB to leave its three key rates unchanged. Will the ECB unveil their blueprint for winding down their PSPP or will they ‘kick the can down the road’ to July? Questions likely to be raised on the Bank’s view surrounding the latest developments in Italian politics. Macro projections likely to see oil prices curtail 2018 growth expectations whilst lifting inflation prospects, For the full preview click here.

Daily FX Wrap: a degree of hawkish hedging ahead of the Fed
content:
USD

Eroding more gains across the board as the clock ticks down to the FOMC in what looks like a classic profit-take and position paring move in the event that the outcome is not as hawkish as generally expected, and given that a 25 bp tightening is already well priced in. Note, the index and Dollar overall only got a knee-jerk lift from firmer than forecast PPI metrics, as a result, with the DXY dipping below 93.700 vs a fraction under 94.000 at one stage.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi has emerged (gradually) as G10 high-flyer on nothing specific or independent, but more on supportive cross winds as its antipodean peer failed to shrug off dovish RBA commentary and Governor Lowe lamenting low wages and their impact on overall inflation again. Nzd/Usd nudged a bit further above 0.7000 towards 0.7050, while Aud/Usd was capped ahead of 0.7600 and Aud/Nzd remained south of 1.0800 after reports of persistent offers during the Asian session in both pairs.

EUR/CAD/CHF   

All beneficiaries from the broad Greenback downturn, with the single currency edging up towards 1.1800 (where big layered expiry interest lies) and a fib levels (1.1762) and the Loonie bouncing firmly from 1.3000+ lows after 1.3050 offers were just untouched and consequently a strong chart resistance level held (1.3067 – high from June 5 and close to a longer term trend-line). Usd/Chf slipped back to 0.9850 vs a high just short of 0.9900.

JPY/GBP

Pretty much the underperformers all day, but both off worst levels and Usd/Jpy back under a 50% fib (110.62) to a fresh session low, while Cable has recovered from partly UK CPI-related weakness and a test of support ahead of 1.3300 to trade at 1.3350+ again.

EM

Some respite for the Lira, Real and Rand on a combination of tech retracement, ongoing official intervention, data and pure short covering alongside the aforementioned Usd retreat.

RANsquawk EU Mid Session - DXY knocking on the door of 94.000 ahead of FOMC rate decision - 13th June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European bourses are largely negative (Eurostoxx 50 -0.4%) ahead of the FOMC rate decision. The outperforming index is currently the FTSE MIB (+0.3%), with the IBEX down 0.6% following disappointing earnings from index heavy-weight Inditex.

The approval of AT&T’s merger with Time Warner by a US judge, is an event in focus by traders, as this could lead to M&A follow through, with specific focus on Sky and Deutsche Telekom.

Glencore (+2.3%) has seen the resolution of Gécamines’ litigation in DR Congo following the writing off of USD 5.6bln in their subsidiary Katanga Mining.

Dixons Carphone (-3.6%) is the latest co. to be hit by a data breach, with 105k payment cards compromised, and 1.2m records containing non-financial personal data.

FX

DXY

The index is on a firmer footing again, ahead of the Fed and with the Greenback gaining ground vs most major peers apart from the antipodean dollars that are managing to stay on an even keel even though underlying energy/metal prices are weak, and for the AUD more dovish RBA commentary has hardly helped the cause. The DXY is hovering just below 94.000 and looking for anything further to keep the momentum going from the FOMC beyond an already factored in 25 bp hike.

GBP

The G10 laggard, and once again undermined by UK data to a degree as CPI remained unchanged in May (m/m and y/y) vs some expectations for an uptick. Cable is drifting down towards 1.3300 as a result, while also eyeing the 2nd day of Brexit bill debate and voting before attention turns to the Fed.

JPY/CHF/CAD

All extending recent loss vs the Dollar as Usd/Jpy finally soaks up all offers around 110.50 to trade up at 110.70 and technically through another key resistance level (110.62 Fib), while Usd/Chf is back in the upper end of a broad 0.9850-0.9900 band after mixed Swiss data (y/y PPI firmer than previous, but industrial orders slowed markedly). The Loonie is back under pressure and sub-1.3000 again vs its US counterpart as the NA disharmony continues to impact, and 1.3050 is the next upside chart target in sight.

EUR

Holding around 1.1750 vs the Usd amidst expectations that the ECB will live up to recent more hawkish impulses (via sources and GC officials) tomorrow, but also checked by very large option expiries ranging from 1.1700-1.1800 and just above.

NZD

A marginal outperformer, but mainly as a bi-product of relative weakness in the Aud as mentioned earlier, with the Kiwi keeping its head above 0.7000 vs the Usd and the cross retreating to sub-1.0800 territory.

EM/SCANDI

It’s a case of more pain and more gain for the likes of the Lira vs Kronas as Usd/Try is back up near 4.7000 and pre-CRBT hike levels on heightened Turkish election jitters, while Eur/Sek and Eur/Nok trade at fresh multi-month lows after another upbeat regional survey (Riksbank hot on the heels of Norges Bank yesterday). Eur/Sek down through 10.1300 and Eur/Nok around 9.4250 at one stage.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts extended their Liffe peak to 122.15 (+32 ticks) in wake of the benign vs expectations UK CPI data, and Bunds piggy-backed to post a fresh Eurex session high at 160.18 (+33 ticks) before both were hauled back by a really meek reception for the 10 year German auction. The benchmarks are now back to within a few ticks of parity, but Italian BTPs did inch a bit further towards 126.00 again at 125.94 (+125 ticks) before easing back in wake of Italian supply that went down better, albeit with higher premiums, outright and relative. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are treading a very tight line ahead of the FOMC, but could see some interim price action after PPI.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued overnight amid a slightly firmer USD with WTI crude futures also hampered by an unexpected build in API crude inventories, with the pressure exacerbated on a break below USD 66.00/bbl and the prior session’s lows. This also came in the context of source reports suggesting Russia are to seek a rollback on oil cuts for most OPEC+ nations and propose OPEC+ share out 1.8mln bpd quota increase, with the plan said to leave 1mln bpd of involuntary oil cuts intact.

In European trade, oil broke back above the USD 66.00/bbl level in the wake of the IEA monthly report forecasting stable oil demand, as well as Iranian and Venezuelan oil output possibly falling by almost 30%. The fossil fuel is still negative for the day, however, at USD 66.20/bbl.

Further news in the oil sector emanated from the Kremlin with Russian President Putin not planning to discuss an exit from the global oil output deal with Saudi Crown Prince at their World Cup meeting.

In the metals scope Gold and base metals are all lower with traders tentative ahead of the FOMC’s rate decision later in the day.

subject: Fixed Income: data spike hits supply issues
content: Gilts extended their Liffe peak to 122.15 (+32 ticks) in wake of the benign vs expectations UK CPI data, and Bunds piggy-backed to post a fresh Eurex session high at 160.18 (+33 ticks) before both were hauled back by a really meek reception for the 10 year German auction. The benchmarks are now back to within a few ticks of parity, but Italian BTPs did inch a bit further towards 126.00 again at 125.94 (+125 ticks) before easing back in wake of Italian supply that went down better, albeit with higher premiums, outright and relative. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are treading a very tight line ahead of the FOMC, but could see some interim price action after PPI.

subject: Germany sells EUR 1.535bln vs. Exp. EUR 2bln 0.5% 2028 Bund with a b/c 1.1 (Prev. b/c 2.78), average yield 0.48% (Prev. 0.62%) and retention 23.25% (Prev. 20.5%)
Russia is to propose to participants of the oil output cut deal that they increase output in line with quotas, in order to remove the risk of the market overheating, according to a government source
FX Morning Colour: Usd perky pre-Powell, Gbp downbeat post-data
content:
DXY

The index is on a firmer footing again, ahead of the Fed and with the Greenback gaining ground vs most major peers apart from the antipodean dollars that are managing to stay on an even keel even though underlying energy/metal prices are weak, and for the AUD more dovish RBA commentary has hardly helped the cause. The DXY is hovering just below 94.000 and looking for anything further to keep the momentum going from the FOMC beyond an already factored in 25 bp hike.

GBP

The G10 laggard, and once again undermined by UK data to a degree as CPI remained unchanged in May (m/m and y/y) vs some expectations for an uptick. Cable is drifting down towards 1.3300 as a result, while also eyeing the 2nd day of Brexit bill debate and voting before attention turns to the Fed.

JPY/CHF/CAD

All extending recent loss vs the Dollar as Usd/Jpy finally soaks up all offers around 110.50 to trade up at 110.70 and technically through another key resistance level (110.62 Fib), while Usd/Chf is back in the upper end of a broad 0.9850-0.9900 band after mixed Swiss data (y/y PPI firmer than previous, but industrial orders slowed markedly). The Loonie is back under pressure and sub-1.3000 again vs its US counterpart as the NA disharmony continues to impact, and 1.3050 is the next upside chart target in sight.

EUR

Holding around 1.1750 vs the Usd amidst expectations that the ECB will live up to recent more hawkish impulses (via sources and GC officials) tomorrow, but also checked by very large option expiries ranging from 1.1700-1.1800 and just above.

NZD

A marginal outperformer, but mainly as a bi-product of relative weakness in the Aud as mentioned earlier, with the Kiwi keeping its head above 0.7000 vs the Usd and the cross retreating to sub-1.0800 territory.

EM/SCANDI

It’s a case of more pain and more gain for the likes of the Lira vs Kronas as Usd/Try is back up near 4.7000 and pre-CRBT hike levels on heightened Turkish election jitters, while Eur/Sek and Eur/Nok trade at fresh multi-month lows after another upbeat regional survey (Riksbank hot on the heels of Norges Bank yesterday). Eur/Sek down through 10.1300 and Eur/Nok around 9.4250 at one stage.

UK debt and STIR futures : narrowly mixed ahead of UK CPI and FOMC
content: The Short Sterling strip is essentially coasting into today’s domestic inflation data in very low-key volumes from the start of Wednesday’s session that also features the Fed of course, albeit out of EU hours, while Gilts are trading a tad more choppily either side of Tuesday’s 121.83 Liffe settlement price within a 121.73-83 range, but again amidst relatively light turnover as many market participants err on the side of caution before the aforementioned big events. UK CPI is seen holding steady to slightly firmer, but higher oil prices and Gbp weakness is expected to lift PPI metrics, so could be more pertinent for bonds and STIRs following yesterday’s mixed jobs/earnings release and the broadly weaker industrial data on Monday.

Bunds: on the rebound from early lows and decoupling?
content: A marked change in the early pattern of trade seen so far this week and some signs that German/core Eurozone bonds are not as sensitive to moves at the margins, with the 10 year benchmark bouncing from worst levels seen after an initial Eurex markdown (to 159.80) at 159.75 and currently probing just above 160.00 – 160.03 peak vs yesterday’s 159.85 close. Meanwhile, Italian BTPs have rallied to 125.65 for a 96 tick again on the day after more official ‘assurances’ that the country intends to stick with the Eur, and perhaps more poignantly not making a concession for upcoming supply. On that note, Germany is tapping Eur2 bn 2028 debt with a 0.5% coupon and the equivalent cash yield is currently around 0.48% having hit circa 0.51% peaks of late. Ahead, Spanish inflation data, pan Eurozone employment and ip all slated.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

13th June 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded subdued with participants tentative ahead of the looming FOMC decision later today. ASX 200 (-0.6%) was dragged by weakness in energy and financials, although upside was seen in APA Group which surged over 20% after Cheung Kong Infrastructure made an offer for the Co. valued at AUD 13bln. This was also in tandem with a plethora of M&A newsflow overnight that began stateside after a US judge ruled AT&T could proceed with its acquisition of Time Warner without any conditions imposed, which in turn underpinned several media and telecom names on the prospects of open M&A floodgates. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) outperformed and was kept afloat by JPY weakness, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) and Hang Seng (-0.6%) were lower amid expectations of a looming Fed hike and China to follow suit by raising rates on its repo and lending facilities. Today saw the resumption of trade for ZTE shares from a 2-month halt which hit limit down in Shenzhen and dropped around 40% in Hong Kong after agreeing to pay a USD 1.4bln penalty to the US, while trade concerns also resurfaced as President Trump stated that USD 80bln agriculture purchase commitment from China and with trade adviser Navarro suggesting that Trump is to impose some tariffs on China. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid similar uneventful trade in T-notes and a tentative tone in riskier assets, while the BoJ Rinban announcement also failed to spur demand with the total amount at a reserved JPY 505bln.

FTSE

Sky (SKY LN)/Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – A Judge has cleared the AT&T/Time Warner merger opposed by Trump. Note, CNBC reported on Monday that a possible passing of this merger could lead to a cascading effect on more M&A action for other companies and offer more credence to the passage of the T-Mobile/Sprint merger. This could also have repercussions for the Disney/21st Century Fox deal, wherein Comcast have stated that if this deal was allowed, they would make an offer for the 21st Century Fox parts that the Walt Disney Company is in the process of acquiring for USD 52.4bln in stock. (Newswires)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – a parliamentary committee is to question the CEO’s of Sainsbury’s and Asda ahead of the proposed merger. (Newswires)

Glencore (GLEN LN) – The co. has written off USD 5.6bln to end the legal dispute in Congo with Gécamines. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

TATE & LYLE (TATE LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT JEFFERIESDAX

Fraport (FRA GY) – Passenger traffic +9.5% in May, airport cargo -1.6%. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY) – The car co. is to recall cars in Britain due to their emissions cheating scandal. (Times)

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) – The co.’s supervisory board will meet to discuss the planned JV with Tata Steel. This is facing some pressure form shareholders and labour leaders, as according to some sources. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

WACKER CHEMIE (WCH GY) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERGCAC

BNP Paribas (BNP FP)/Deutsche Bank (DBK GY)/SocGen (GLE FP) – ECB is looking in to the trading books of the aforementioned co.’s over securities pricing. (Newswires)

Société Générale (GLE FP) – The co.’s Belgian unit is up for sale. (L’Echo)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air France (AF FP) – Co.’s pilots union states that it has not resumed talks with management of the Co. (Newswires)

SMI

Richemont (CFR SW) – The co. has reported that 3.3% of Yoox Net-a-Porter’s (YNAP IM) share capital was tendered in a sell-out procedure. Richemont now own 98.4% on YNAP at the end of the sell-out period. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

Inditex (ITX SM) – Q1 Net income +2% to EUR 668mln vs. Exp. EUR 644mln, EBITDA EUR 1.13bln vs. prev. EUR 1.11bln, net sales EUR 5.65bln vs. Exp. EUR 5.82bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ASML (ASML NA) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC

US

SPX +0.17%, NDX +0.57%, DJI -0.01%.

SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.40%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.02%, Energy: -0.76%, Financials: -0.26%, Health Care: -0.12%, Industrials: -0.04%, Materials: +0.07%, Telecoms: -0.32%, Tech: +0.41%, Utilities: +1.15%.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks traded subdued with participants tentative ahead of the looming FOMC decision and amid a resurfacing of trade concerns
content:
Asian stocks traded subdued with participants tentative ahead of the looming FOMC decision and amid a resurfacing of trade concerns

House of Commons rejected withdrawal bill amendments related to Brexit day, Henry VIII powers and ‘meaningful vote’

Looking ahead, highlights include IEA monthly oil report, UK CPI, US PPI, DoEs, FOMC rate decision and press conference, supply from Italy and Germany

ASIA

Asian stocks traded subdued with participants tentative ahead of the looming FOMC decision later today. ASX 200 (-0.6%) was dragged by weakness in energy and financials, although upside was seen in APA Group which surged over 20% after Cheung Kong Infrastructure made an offer for the Co. valued at AUD 13bln. This was also in tandem with a plethora of M&A newsflow overnight that began stateside after a US judge ruled AT&T could proceed with its acquisition of Time Warner without any conditions imposed, which in turn underpinned several media and telecom names on the prospects of open M&A floodgates. Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) outperformed and was kept afloat by JPY weakness, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) and Hang Seng (-0.6%) were lower amid expectations of a looming Fed hike and China to follow suit by raising rates on its repo and lending facilities. Today saw the resumption of trade for ZTE shares from a 2-month halt which hit limit down in Shenzhen and dropped around 40% in Hong Kong after agreeing to pay a USD 1.4bln penalty to the US, while trade concerns also resurfaced as President Trump stated that USD 80bln agriculture purchase commitment from China and with trade adviser Navarro suggesting that Trump is to impose some tariffs on China. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat amid similar uneventful trade in T-notes and a tentative tone in riskier assets, while the BoJ Rinban announcement also failed to spur demand with the total amount at a reserved JPY 505bln. 

US President Trump said USD 80bln agriculture purchase commitment from China was insufficient. (Fox News) In related news, there were also comments from White House trade adviser Navarro that President Trump is planning to impose tariffs on a subset of China imports that were part of an initial list of around USD 50bln in goods, while reports also noted speculation this could be in place as soon as Friday. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 40bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 30bln via 28-day reverse repos, for a net daily injection of CNY 70bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4256 (Prev. 6.4121)


UK/EU

House of Commons backed the government and voted to reject withdrawal bill amendments related to Brexit day, Henry VIII powers and ‘meaningful vote’ which would have given parliament more say in Brexit negotiations, with rebel Conservative MPs said to have agreed to back the government on concession that further changes would follow. The concessions saw PM May give in to demands from pro-EU MPs that parliament should be consulted on whether “no deal is better than a bad deal”. Furthermore, Solicitor General Buckland said he would be open to discussing the Grieve amendment with a view to accepting some or all of it in a new amendment in the Lords. (Newswires/Guardian)

The Telegraph reports that the Best for Britain group has held a series of talks with Remain-supporting ministers and MPs to encourage them to oppose Theresa May. (Telegraph)

German Chancellor Merkel said the US would have a large surplus with EU if services were included in calculations and stated that she has lobbied against one-sided car tariffs with the US. (Newswires)


FX

FX markets were relatively quiet with the DXY marginally extending on the prior day’s gains ahead of an anticipated Fed rate hike and after reports that Fed Chair Powell was considering conducting press conferences after every Fed meeting, which could essentially make every meeting ‘live’. EUR/USD and GBP/USD were flat and languished near US-session lows, which provided the latter with some respite from the Brexit-related swings before another day of amendment voting at the House of Commons later. Elsewhere, JPY extended on weakness and commodity-linked currencies were also lacklustre amid recent softness in the energy and metal prices.
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued overnight amid a slightly firmer USD. As such, WTI crude futures were lower following an unexpected build in API crude inventories, with the pressure exacerbated on a break below USD 66.00/bbl as well as the prior session’s lows. Elsewhere, price action in gold was contained by pre-FOMC caution and copper weakened alongside a risk averse tone and underperformance in its largest consumer China.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (8 Jun) +0.800M vs. Exp. -2.700M (Prev. -2.028M). (Newswires)

Russia is said to seek a rollback on oil cuts for most OPEC+ nations and propose OPEC+ share out 1.8mln bpd quota increase, while the plan said to leave 1mln bpd of involuntary oil cuts intact. (Newswires)

EIA raised forecast for 2018 world oil demand by 40,000 and sees increase 1.801mln bpd Y/Y, while it cut forecasts for 2019 growth by 10,000 bpd and sees increase of 1.72mln bpd Y/Y. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said US will not be conducting war games as long as it is negotiating in good faith with North Korea and stated that North Korea denuclearization is expected to begin immediately. (Newswires) However, US forces in South Korea had earlier stated they have not received updated guidance on the execution or cessation of training exercises and there were also reports US Vice President Pence told Republicans that military exercises in Korea will carry on. (abcNEWS/Newswires/Twitter)

US President Trump tweeted there is no limit what North Korea can achieve if it gives up nuclear weapons and embraces commerce & engagement with the world, while he also wanted to thank North Korea Leader Kim for taking first bold step towards a bright new future for his people. (Twitter)

North Korea said US President Trump agreed in summit to lift sanctions against North Korea and offer North Korea security, while North Korea also stated that US President Trump agreed to step-by-step denuclearization by the North in return for US concessions. (KCNA)

North Korean Leader Kim praised US President Trump's will to resolve issues and that both sides should commit to avoid antagonizing each other while he suggested legal and institutional steps to guarantee it. Furthermore, Kim also said it is urgent for both sides to make bold decision to halt irritating and hostile military actions. (KCNA)

US

The treasuries complex was drifting lower in pre-market trade ahead of US CPI data, and Wednesday’s FOMC rate decision. Action was generally contained within narrow ranges. Most of the action was in the front end of the curve where 2yr and 5yr yields were up by c.2bps at settlement. 2s30 and 5s30s widened by c.1bps. The US Treasury auctioned $14bln of 30-year notes, tailing by 0.1bps; demand was firm, with indirects taking down above recent averages. US 10YR T-note futures (Sep 2018) 1 tick lower at 119-13.

Fed Chair Jerome Powell is reportedly considering following all Fed meetings with a press conference. (WSJ)

AT&T (T) won US court approval to purchase Time Warner (TWX) for USD 85bln with no conditions imposed, while the judge urged the government not to seek a stay in ruling which he would deny if requested. (Newswires) 

Canada's Foreign Minister Freeland said Canada is hoping for the best but prepared for the worst regarding NAFTA and that she is expected to meet US Trade Representative Lighthizer this week/ Furthermore, Freeland stated Canadian PM Trudeau raised issue of autos tariffs ' very clearly' with US President Trump last week and that she is prepared for any eventuality over auto tariffs

content:
TAIWAN
